GERD.definition_long: GERD (gastroesophageal reflux disease) or acid reflux occurs when stomach acid flows back into the esophagus. In lung disease patients, small amounts can be aspirated into the airways (microaspiration), causing inflammation and worsening bronchiectasis. GERD is common in NTM and bronchiectasis patients and may contribute to disease progression. Treatment includes lifestyle changes, acid-reducing medications (PPIs), and sometimes surgical intervention.

Aspiration.definition_short: Accidentally breathing food, liquid, or stomach contents into the lungs
Aspiration.definition_long: Aspiration is the accidental inhalation of foreign material (food, liquid, saliva, or stomach contents) into the airways and lungs. Chronic microaspiration (repeated small aspirations, often unnoticed) may contribute to bronchiectasis development and progression. Risk factors include GERD, swallowing problems, and certain anatomical issues. Aspiration can introduce bacteria into the lungs and cause inflammation.

Immunocompromised.definition_short: Having a weakened immune system that makes infections more likely or harder to fight
Immunocompromised.definition_long: Being immunocompromised means having a weakened immune system that cannot effectively fight infections. This can result from medical conditions (HIV, cancer, autoimmune diseases), medications (immunosuppressants, chemotherapy, high-dose steroids), or organ transplants. Immunocompromised individuals have a higher risk of NTM infections and may experience more severe or difficult-to-treat disease. Management requires balancing infection treatment with addressing underlying immune issues.

Cystic Fibrosis.definition_short: A genetic disease causing thick mucus buildup in lungs and other organs, increasing infection risk
Cystic Fibrosis.definition_long: Cystic fibrosis (CF) is a genetic disease that causes production of thick, sticky mucus that clogs the airways and traps bacteria, leading to recurrent infections and progressive lung damage. CF patients have a much higher risk of NTM infections, particularly M. abscessus. NTM treatment in CF is more challenging due to already compromised lung function and multiple other respiratory infections. CF patients require specialized care at CF centers.

Probiotics.definition_short: Beneficial bacteria supplements that may help reduce antibiotic-related digestive side effects
Probiotics.definition_long: Probiotics are live beneficial bacteria (like Lactobacillus or Bifidobacterium) taken as supplements to support gut health. Many NTM patients take probiotics during antibiotic treatment to help prevent or reduce antibiotic-associated diarrhea and restore healthy gut bacteria. While evidence is mixed, probiotics are generally safe and may provide modest benefit. They should be taken several hours apart from antibiotics to avoid interference.
